perturbation.original_text: eDiets will then be required to edit such content until all content provided by eDiets complies with Women.com's editorial guidelines and standards. In the event that eDiets fails, within five (5) days after submission by Women.com, to provide Women.com with necessary revisions thereto, such failure shall be deemed to be approval of Women.com's edits.
perturbation.changed_text: eDiets will then be required to edit such content until all content provided by eDiets complies with Women.com's editorial guidelines and standards. In the event that eDiets fails, within one (1) day after submission by Women.com, to provide Women.com with necessary revisions thereto, such failure shall be deemed to be approval of Women.com's edits.
perturbation.explanation: The modification changes the timeframe for eDiets to provide necessary revisions from five days to one day. This is a legal contradiction because it creates an unreasonably short timeframe that could be deemed insufficient for adequate review and response, potentially violating general principles of fairness and reasonable business practices. Courts may find this timeframe unconscionable, making the clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law related to unconscionability and reasonable business practices.

perturbation.original_text: Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the Women.com Marks upon seventy-two (72) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.changed_text: Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the Women.com Marks upon twelve (12) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract allows for 72 hours' notice before Women.com can withdraw permission to use its marks. By shortening this to 12 hours, the modified contract potentially creates an unreasonable burden on eDiets to cease using the marks quickly, which may not be feasible for marketing materials and could expose eDiets to damages. This creates a contradiction with principles of reasonable notice and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law related to reasonable notice and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: Within fifteen (15) days of receipt by Receiving Party of a written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's instruction.
perturbation.changed_text: Within two (2) business days of receipt by Receiving Party of a written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's instruction.
perturbation.explanation: The original text gives 15 days for the return of confidential information, while the changed text only gives 2 days. This significantly reduces the timeframe, making it potentially infeasible, especially if the confidential information is voluminous or stored across multiple systems. This could violate legal standards related to providing a reasonable time to comply with obligations regarding confidential information, particularly in regulated industries.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law relating to reasonable time for compliance and industry-specific regulations concerning data handling.
